Welte-Mignon* Reproducing Action makes that
                piano reproduce with absolute perfection the playing of the master pianists.
Brings to your home

The science of musical reproduction has progressed
                        through the various stages-experiment, medioc-
                        rity, excellence-but until the introduction of the
                        Welte-Mignon
                        it has never reached supreme per-
                        fection. But today the science has reached its
                        apex, the goal has been attained and beyond the splendid
                        achievement realized in the Welte-Mignon it is im-
                        possible to go.

It perpetuates these performances so that fu-
                        ture generations will enjoy the music of our
                        present-day virtuosos when their personalities are
                        but misty memories.

What the Victor is doing for the famous singers
                        of the world the Welte-Mignon is
                        accomplishing for the pianists.

thereby reproducing in every detail of
                        touch, tone and technique the actual
                        renditions of the pianists, in every sense their original per-
                        formances.

His expectant New York
            audience at once recognized his native genius, genuine musicianship, and
            brilliant command of the piano.

the accuracy and perfection

the second

. . . A women relaxes in the soft depths of
                her favorite chair . . .

On the table by her
                side rests a small tablet with eight ivory but-
                tons . . . She presses . . . From her
                superb piano, a WELTE-MIGNON, flow the
                magic strains of a Chopin Nocturne . . .
                Paderewski is playing . . . Silence for a mo-
                ment . . . the silence of appreciation . . .
                She touches another button, chossing at ran-
                dom . . . Josef Hofmann-playing
                Medels-
                sohn's "Rondo Capriccioso."

In modern mood
                she turns to Gershwin . . . "The Rhap-
                sody in Blue" . . .

For an hour or more, she
                revels in the worlds great piano music . . .
                never moving from her chair

Every
                annoying interruption is banished . . . no
                dials to turn . . . no rerolling . . .
                no changing of records.
                The Musicalle is a cabinet containing eight
                records and the silent mechanism for control-
                ling them.

Perfect Reproducing – The Secret of Welte Mignon
Perfect Reproducing – The Secret of Welte Mignon

The Welte-Mignon method of recording
                a player's performance is photographic.
                Through this
                
                    secret photographic process
                -
                possessed only by Welte-Mignon,* available
                only to Welte-Mignon* - the artist's play-
                ing is actually photographed – his tempo, his
                speaking notes, his dynamics,
                
                    those subtle
                    things that infuse an artist's very soul into
                    his playing.

                whether ever so lightly-pianissimo-or with

with all the
                skill, warmth and color, and all the

                in person.

The highest achievement of the House
                    of Welte in the world of music in-
                    vention

whereby generations yet unborn may
                    listen to

accurate and authentic interpreta-
                    tions upon the piano,
Living Soul of the Artist

So accurately does the Welte reproduce each note-each delicate
                shade of contrast-and the individuality of the player, that famous critics
                declare it impossible to believe that the artist is not actually playing.
most remarkable musical invention of our age.

The Welte-Mignon can be likened to a college for teaching
                the art of playing the piano.
                This college has a faculty of one hundred fifty-six instructors-the
                leading pianists of this generation.
                These master pianists have interpreted over five thousand different
                pieces of the best musical literature of all ages of which each inter-
                pretation is an authoritative instruction in
                the playing off that particular composition
                -a final lesson in the art of finished piano playing.
                 playing.
                The Welte-Mignon is the means
                through which this great storehouse of cor-
                rect and artistic piano playing is given to
                the public-the student and layman, alike.
                All of the great musical conservatories of
                the world, if taken together, could not com-
                mand a faculty of such combined power
                and genius as the faculty of piano inter-
                pretation employed by the Welte-
                Mignon.
                Nor can all the combined musical schools find it within
                their means to render the great masterpieces of musical
                literature with such authority as can the Welte
                Mignon.
